articles.headline: It Was a Hot Real Estate Trade. Now Investors Are Worried.
articles.snippet: Drawn by the opportunity to invest with private equity firms, small investors rushed into real estate investment trusts. But the funds have lost some appeal as interest rates have climbed.
articles.abstract: Drawn by the opportunity to invest with private equity firms, small investors rushed into real estate investment trusts. But the funds have lost some appeal as interest rates have climbed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Given the opportunity to park money with the world’s largest private equity firms, ordinary investors rushed in. Getting out might not be so easy.

articles.headline: Harris Says Trump Will Repeal Obamacare. Trump Now Claims He’ll Make It ‘Better.’
articles.snippet: The popularity of the Affordable Care Act has changed the political strategy of Republicans, who are no longer campaigning to end the law.
articles.abstract: The popularity of the Affordable Care Act has changed the political strategy of Republicans, who are no longer campaigning to end the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz, the Minnesota governor, have quickly made the Affordable Care Act central to their campaign, raising the specter of another Republican repeal effort next year if former President Donald J. Trump wins the White House.

articles.headline: Immigrants Are Becoming U.S. Citizens at Fastest Clip in Years
articles.snippet: The government has reduced a backlog of applications that built up during the Trump administration. New citizens say they are looking forward to voting in November.
articles.abstract: The government has reduced a backlog of applications that built up during the Trump administration. New citizens say they are looking forward to voting in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government is processing citizenship requests at the fastest clip in a decade, moving rapidly through a backlog that built up during the Trump administration and the coronavirus pandemic.

articles.headline: Worried About a Convention Clash, Democrats Woo Uncommitted Delegates
articles.snippet: A quiet diplomatic effort to ease tensions with uncommitted delegates and head off televised confrontations inside the Democratic convention hall next week has been underway for months.
articles.abstract: A quiet diplomatic effort to ease tensions with uncommitted delegates and head off televised confrontations inside the Democratic convention hall next week has been underway for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators are expected in the streets and the parks of Chicago for next week’s Democratic National Convention, most of them to protest the U.S. role in the war in Gaza. But officials are concerned about the potential for a more embarrassing spectacle: prime-time disruptions inside the arena itself.

articles.headline: At a Russian Border Post, Scenes of Ruin After Ukraine’s Surprise Attack
articles.snippet: A week after the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited one of the spots where Ukrainian forces stormed into Russia and surprised the defenders.
articles.abstract: A week after the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited one of the spots where Ukrainian forces stormed into Russia and surprised the defenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: All that remained of a Russian border post was a tableau of destruction: Sheet metal flapped in the wind, customs declarations fluttered about, and stray dogs roamed under a road-spanning sign that said, “Russia.”
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

articles.headline: Can This Country Show Europe How to Compete Again?
articles.snippet: Sweden outperforms in tech, has a roster of $1 billion-plus start-ups and could be a model as the European Union refigures its growth policies.
articles.abstract: Sweden outperforms in tech, has a roster of $1 billion-plus start-ups and could be a model as the European Union refigures its growth policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sweden’s economy has, in many ways, suffered from the same tribulations as the rest of Europe: recent bouts of crushing inflation and recession, and now the prospect of meager growth in a world split by geopolitical and economic conflict.

articles.headline: Israel Was Less Flexible in Recent Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Documents Show
articles.snippet: The country made five new demands, according to documents detailing its newest negotiating positions.
articles.abstract: The country made five new demands, according to documents detailing its newest negotiating positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has denied that he is trying to block a cease-fire deal in Gaza by hardening Israel’s negotiating position. Mr. Netanyahu has consistently placed all blame for the deadlocked negotiations on Hamas, even as senior members of the Israeli security establishment accused him of slowing the process himself.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Starbucks Replaces C.E.O. With Chipotle’s Brian Niccol
articles.snippet: The coffee chain said that Chipotle’s chief executive would replace Laxman Narasimhan, who is leaving the company after just over a year at the helm.
articles.abstract: The coffee chain said that Chipotle’s chief executive would replace Laxman Narasimhan, who is leaving the company after just over a year at the helm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starbucks, facing slowing sales for its lattes and Frappuccinos, a slumping stock and agitation from activist investors, abruptly ousted its chief executive on Tuesday, replacing him with the chief executive of Chipotle Mexican Grill.
articles.byline: By Danielle Kaye and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Musk’s Trump Talk: After Glitchy Start, a Two-Hour Ramble
articles.snippet: Problems in the livestream renewed questions about X’s ability to handle big events, but it also showed how the platform can still grab attention.
articles.abstract: Problems in the livestream renewed questions about X’s ability to handle big events, but it also showed how the platform can still grab attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 8:35 p.m. Eastern time on Monday, a live audio stream on X of a conversation between Elon Musk and former President Donald J. Trump flickered to life after a 35-minute delay — but only for a moment.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Ryan Mac

articles.headline: How Food Prices Have Changed Over the Past Four Years
articles.snippet: Grocery prices are no longer rising as rapidly, but food inflation remains a top issue for voters, polls show.
articles.abstract: Grocery prices are no longer rising as rapidly, but food inflation remains a top issue for voters, polls show.
articles.lead_paragraph: A central issue has plagued the Biden administration for most of its term: the steep rise in grocery prices.

articles.headline: Arizona Will Vote on Abortion in November: Could That Give Democrats an Edge?
articles.snippet: Arizona, a swing state, and Missouri will be among the states voting on whether to establish abortion rights in state constitutions. Democrats have used the issue to turn out voters.
articles.abstract: Arizona, a swing state, and Missouri will be among the states voting on whether to establish abortion rights in state constitutions. Democrats have used the issue to turn out voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Arizona voters will decide in November whether to establish a right to abortion in the state constitution, a measure that could strongly influence turnout in a battleground state crucial to the presidential election and control of the Senate.
